metadata.feature_description: Ensures Google Analytics connector works correctly in Azure cloud environment

test_scenarios.scenario_name: Verify connector accessibility and basic functionality on localhost (Azure-compatible patterns)

steps.action: Logged in as SuperUser and navigated to Connectors panel
steps.expected: Connectors panel should load and display Google Analytics 4 connector
steps.actual: Connectors panel loaded successfully. Google Analytics 4 connector displayed with green checkmark indicating it is connected and an Edit button

steps.action: Clicked Edit button on Google Analytics 4 connector to view configuration
steps.expected: Connector configuration panel should expand showing settings
steps.actual: Configuration panel expanded successfully showing Measurement ID (UA-12345678-1), Track for Administrators checkbox (checked), and Cancel/Save buttons. Settings are editable.

observations: CRITICAL: Test environment is localhost:8081, NOT an Azure deployment. Azure-specific test scenarios (connector installation on Azure, token storage in Azure, API calls from Azure, script injection on Azure, performance/scalability on Azure, Azure security requirements) cannot be tested without actual Azure deployment.

Code review confirmed Azure compatibility through: (1) <azureCompatible>true</azureCompatible> declaration in DNNXE_GoogleAnalyticsConnector.dnn manifest at line 20, (2) Settings stored in database via HostController/PortalController (not file system - which is Azure-compatible), (3) Token caching uses Evoq Microservices Framework TokenCachedService designed for cloud environments, (4) No Azure-specific code paths exist - Azure compatibility is achieved through standard DNN/Evoq patterns that inherently support Azure Web Apps.
The connector uses external API endpoint (https://dnnapi.com/analytics) which would work identically from localhost or Azure environments.

On localhost, the connector loads successfully, settings can be viewed/edited, and basic functionality operates - this same behavior would be expected in Azure since the code uses Azure-compatible storage and API patterns.
